qas.question: What are the tourist hotspots in Portugal?

answers.text: Lisbon, Algarve, Madeira, Porto and the city of Coimbra

qas.question: Where do 4-5 million religious pilgrims visit in Portugal every year?
What apparitions reportedly took place in 1917?

answers.text: Blessed Virgin Mary to three shepherd children

qas.question: What tourist destinations are the Portuguese government continuing to promote and develop?

answers.text: Douro Valley, the island of Porto Santo, and Alentejo

qas.question: What is the 16th European city to attract the most tourists?

context: Tourist hotspots in Portugal are <a0_0>Lisbon, Algarve, Madeira, Porto and the city of Coimbra<a0_0/>, also, between 4-5 million religious pilgrims visit <a1_0>Fátima<a1_0/> each year, where apparitions of the <a2_0>Blessed Virgin Mary to three shepherd children<a2_0/> reportedly took place in 1917. The Sanctuary of Fátima is one of the largest Roman Catholic shrines in the world. The Portuguese government continues to promote and develop new tourist destinations, such as the <a3_0>Douro Valley, the island of Porto Santo, and Alentejo<a3_0/>. <a4_0>Lisbon<a4_0/> is the 16th European city which attracts the most tourists (with seven million tourists occupying the city's hotels in 2006, a number that grew 11.8% compared to previous year). Lisbon in recent years surpassed the Algarve as the leading tourist region in Portugal. Porto and Northern Portugal, especially the urban areas north of Douro River valley, was the tourist destination which grew most (11.9%) in 2006, surpassing Madeira (in 2010), as the third most visited destination.[citation needed]
